definition: A serve that lands in the opponent's court without being touched.
A spike directed diagonally across the court.
The steps a hitter takes before jumping for an attack.
An attack made from behind the 3-meter line.
Defensive positioning and play from the back row.
A setter positioned in the back row who can set or attack legally.
The skill of controlling the ball during passes, sets, and attacks.
A defensive play at the net to stop or deflect an attack.
When multiple players help to successfully block an attack.
Positioning teammates to recover balls after a block attempt.
A block that deflects the ball out of bounds off the opponent’s attack.
Extending hands over the net to effectively block an attack.
A player attempting to stop or redirect an opponent’s attack at the net.
A powerful spike aimed at scoring a point.
A serve that hits the floor once before reaching the opponent.
Communication among players regarding ball direction or play strategy.
Illegal handling of the ball where it is momentarily held.
Middle player specializing in blocking attacks at the net.
A set delivered to the middle hitter.
A serve that hits the ceiling and lands in play on the opponent’s side.
Moving quickly to reach a ball that is difficult to reach.
A block where hands are moved together to cover more area.
Positioning to recover balls deflected off a teammate’s attack or block.
A ball hit diagonally across the court from the hitter’s position.
A pass delivered diagonally across the court to a teammate.
Defending balls near the back boundary line.
A serve aimed near the opponent’s backline.
Player specialized in defensive skills, usually back row.
All actions intended to prevent the opponent from scoring.
A defensive move to prevent the ball from hitting the floor.
Two front-row players attempting to block an attack together.
When a player contacts the ball twice consecutively, usually considered a fault.
A setter’s deceptive attack, where they tip or push the ball over the net.
A surprise attack by the setter instead of a set.
Blocking where arms fully extend over the net to intercept the ball.
A pass made while facing the net directly.
Deceptive movement pretending to attack but not hitting.
A quick set designed to surprise blockers.
A deceptive action to trick opponents, often in attacking.
Defensive play to recover balls and keep them in play.
A serve with no spin, causing erratic movement in the air.
Ball moving unpredictably due to lack of spin.
Stepping over the service line while serving.
The movement and positioning of the feet during play.
Attack made by a player positioned in the front row.
Setter positioned in the front row who can attack legally.
Complete defensive positioning behind blockers to recover deflected balls.
Attack aimed at open spaces between blockers.
A point that will win the game if scored.
Defensive play aimed at protecting the back boundary line.
Proper technique of setting the ball using fingers.
A statistic measuring attack efficiency: (kills - errors) ÷ attempts.
Area of the court where attacks are concentrated.
Combination of single and double block strategies.
Attack directed toward the middle of the opponent’s court.
Middle front-row attacker.
A serve combining a jump and no spin for unpredictable motion.
A set performed while the setter jumps to reach higher.
A serve where the player jumps before hitting the ball.
Improvised or unexpected defensive positioning.
Critical area on the court, often near the net or attack zones.
A set delivered slightly later than normal, disrupting timing.
A block aimed to stop a ball going along the sideline.
A spike directed along the sideline.
Arrangement of players for service or rotation.
Specialized defensive player who can replace any back-row player.
A substitution allowing the libero to enter the back row without formal rotation.
A serve aimed deep into the opponent’s court.
A ball not under control by any player.
Attack made by a middle hitter close to the net.
A block executed by the middle front-row player.
Player positioned in the middle front row who attacks and blocks.
Unintended or poorly executed strike of the ball.
Touching the net or crossing it illegally during play.
A slower attack intended to disrupt timing of blockers.
A pass using hands above the head, usually a set.
A serve performed with an overhead motion, often with spin.
A ball accidentally passed over the net by a teammate.
A set made when the offense is not in its ideal formation.
Attack executed by the left-side hitter.
Primary attacker hitting from the left side of the court.
An attack resulting from the opponent’s overpass.
A high, fast set to maximize the hitter’s attack power.
Fast attack immediately after the set to surprise blockers.
Set delivered with minimal time between pass and attack.
Regaining position or control after a play.
Critical area near the net where attacks are most frequent.
The movement of players clockwise after a side-out.
Fault due to incorrect positioning during rotation.
A serve that directly results in a point without being touched by the opponent.
Fault occurring during serving, like hitting out of bounds.
Receiving the opponent’s serve and controlling it for the offense.
The order of serving and player positions in rotation.
Allocation of sets among attackers.
A point that will win the current set if scored.
Speed and timing of the set.
Using different types of sets to confuse the defense.
Block aimed at intercepting a spike.
Serve that lands near the net or short in the opponent’s court.
Serve performed with a sidearm motion.
Winning the serve from the opponent.
Non-verbal cue given by setter or team to indicate play.
Two or more blockers jumping at the same time to block an attack.
Attack using a tip or lightly hitting the ball to place it.
A set delivered quickly to reduce reaction time for blockers.
A serve with spin to make it curve unpredictably.
Formation where attackers line up for coordinated attacks.
Intercepting a ball from the opponent’s attack or serve.
Attack executed from the dominant hitting side.
A blocking technique where hands swing to intercept a ball.
Setter moves arms in a swinging motion to deliver the set.
A light attack over or around blockers.
Defensive positioning after losing the ball.
Offensive play immediately after winning a defensive ball.
Shifting from defense to offense during play.
Two blockers working against one attacker.
Attack made from the non-dominant side of the court.
Blocking on the non-dominant attack side.
An attack that directly results in a point.
The ratio of matches won to total matches played.
Hitting the ball off a blocker’s hands so it goes out of bounds.
Continuous back-and-forth play of the ball over the net.
Defensive strategy where players cover designated areas of the court.
Altering the hitting approach based on set location.
Passing the ball while both feet are off the ground.
Player who stabilizes a rotation or formation.
A block aimed at covering diagonal attacks.
Reading the opponent’s play to react early.
The motion of the arm during a spike or attack.
Area near the net from which attackers hit the ball.
A tip over the net aimed toward the backcourt.
Teammate supporting coverage after a primary play.
Directing the ball to a strategic spot on the court.
Regaining control of a ball after an opponent’s attack.
Following the ball visually to anticipate its trajectory.
The speed at which the ball travels.
Standard defensive positioning before an attack.
Spike aimed near the back boundary line.
The degree hands extend over the net to cover an attack.
Movement from blocking to defensive coverage.
Steps and positioning used to reach the ball at the net.
Aligning the body optimally for attack or defense.
A high-powered spike targeting a weak spot in defense.
Spike that rebounds off the court to gain advantage.
Serve that disrupts the opponent’s formation.
Light contact with the ball during a block to alter trajectory.
Setting the ball using a forearm pass.
Verbal communication to cover an opponent’s attack.
Quickly redirecting the ball after contact.
Positioning of the middle hitter during rotation.
Spike with downward slicing motion for sharp drop.
Key play executed under high-pressure situations.
Bringing hands together at the net to cover more area.
Diagonal trajectory of an attack from hitter to court corner.
Rotation that temporarily positions players outside their usual zone.
A spin serve causing the ball to curve in flight.
Spike with a sharp angled direction.
Soft tip directed toward the opponent’s backcourt.
Area where defenders are positioned to recover blocks or digs.
A set delivered slightly slower than expected to disrupt timing.
Approach to the net from an angle rather than straight on.
Two contacts with the ball in succession, usually a fault.
Two rotations occurring rapidly due to substitutions or errors.
Fast, low-trajectory spike aimed at the opponent’s floor.
Defensive alignment to handle soft tips or off-speed balls.
Deceptive setter attack instead of a normal set.
Jumping before reaching optimal approach timing.
Spike aimed at the sideline or edge of the court.
Recovering a ball that would otherwise hit out-of-bounds.
Foot leaving the ground during a jump or spike.
Longer step pattern before hitting the ball to gain power.
Shoulder rotation outward to increase hitting range.
Setter fakes a set to mislead blockers.
Spike made while jumping backward to maintain balance.
Set intended to prepare a specific hitter for attack.
Ability to observe court positioning and anticipate plays.
Serve moving sharply from side to side in the air.
A quick set with a slight flick of the wrist.
Techniques used to save the ball while diving or sliding.
Defensive contact using feet to stop low balls.
Hit made despite difficult set or position.
Driving the ball toward the opponent’s court aggressively.
Ball returned without attack pressure, usually after a weak hit.
Positioning to recover balls deflected off the front row.
Alignment of attackers near the net in a straight line.
Positioning to cover open spaces left by teammates.
Attack aimed directly along the back boundary line.
Recovering balls near the floor, often requiring dives or rolls.
Partial block by a single player covering only part of the net.
Set delivered with less than full height for a quick attack.
Correct alignment of hands during passing, setting, or blocking.
Powerful serve aimed to overpower opponents.
Defensive alignment to recover attacks.
Order and timing of attacks during a rally.
Synchronizing the attack with the set and blockers.
Direction at which the ball is struck over the net.
Path along which a spike travels.
Attack aimed diagonally toward the court’s outer side.
Gaining control of an opponent’s pass or set.
Spike executed while airborne.
Block made while jumping to reach the ball above the net.
Crucial attack intended to secure a point.
Hit made slightly after the optimal timing to confuse blockers.
Primary offensive attacker in the lineup.
Approach along a straight path to the net.
Serve that lacks speed or placement, easier to receive.
Block executed with minimal jump, emphasizing hand position.
Defensive system where each player marks a specific opponent.
Alignment of middle hitters for quick attack execution.
Soft attack by the middle hitter over blockers.
Failure of teammates to coordinate during a play.
Adjusting approach steps to accommodate set placement.
Understanding of net position during jumps, attacks, and blocks.
All actions occurring near the net, including blocking and tipping.
Positioning to continue attack after the first hit.
Quick set delivered immediately after pass or dig.
Strike using fully open hand to control ball direction.
Arrangement of outside hitters near the sideline.
Soft attack directed toward the court’s edge.
Defensive action using hands above the head to prevent a ball drop.
Hit executed above blockers’ hands.
Defensive readiness for balls deflected over the net.
Set delivered along a line parallel to the net for quick attacks.
Optimal trajectory of the ball during a pass.
Movement of the feet to position properly for a pass.
Block that extends over the net into the opponent’s court.
Positioning around the court edges to intercept attacks.
Recovering a ball that is difficult to control or falling out-of-bounds.
Serve directed sharply toward the edge of the opponent’s court.
A setter’s rotation or movement to create a better attack angle.
Spike directed to a specific open area of the court.
Fault caused by incorrect player positioning during rotation.
Player who directs offensive strategies and sets up attacks.
Set delivered in the narrow space between blockers.
Defensive positioning to ensure a point-winning ball is recovered.
Forceful spike intended to overwhelm blockers.
Strong serve aimed to challenge the receiver’s control.
Hitter’s stance and location before an incoming set.
Rapid positioning after an attack to maintain rally.
Returning to defensive position immediately after an attack or block.
Accelerated steps toward the net for faster attacks.
Extending hands and arms to reach for a ball beyond normal reach.
Spike that changes the ball’s direction mid-air.
Area designated for regaining defensive or offensive positioning.
Attack performed after delaying or holding the set momentarily.
Setter delivers a set to the opposite side of the court than expected.
Defensive positioning after a team rotates.
Ensuring all players move correctly during rotation.
Setter moves around blockers to deliver a set.
Controlled attack aimed at keeping the ball in play.
Jump where one leg moves forward and the other back for balance and reach.
Attack executed after the first attack is blocked or defended.
Player assisting the main blocker at the net.
Spike aimed at gaps between blockers.
Quick set immediately followed by a tip over blockers.
Positioning to cover any blocked or deflected set.
Placing sets precisely to optimize attacker’s advantage.
Adjusting defensive positions in reaction to opponent attack patterns.
Positioning near the net to handle soft attacks.
Reduced steps for a quicker jump and attack.
Soft attack aimed near the net or front row defenders.
Positioning along the sides of the court for defensive coverage.
Alignment of attackers along the sideline for strategic attacks.
Two hitters attack at the same time from different positions.
One player attempting to block an attack.
Ball that touches the court lightly and bounces unpredictably.
High, slow ball sent over the net, often to reset play.
Hitter moves laterally along the net before jumping to attack.
Block designed to redirect the ball rather than stop it completely.
Set delivered with less height or force for controlled attack.
Serve executed with minimal power, often to draw an error.
Positioning to recover the ball after a teammate’s spike is blocked.
Spike imparting spin to alter ball trajectory.
Technique for handling a serve with heavy spin.

Attack performed with teammates aligned behind or beside hitter.

Serve executed without jumping.
Attacker steps forward into the ball to maximize power.
Advancing to the net or ball to intercept attacks.
Serve designed to target weaknesses in opponent formation.
Blocking on the dominant hitting side of the court.
Positioning adjusted for player substitutions during play.
Deceptive tip aimed for maximum placement advantage.
Unexpected hit aimed to catch blockers off-guard.
Attack with full arm swing for maximum power.
Setter uses a wide arm motion to deliver a set.
Soft attack aimed precisely at open court space.
Coordinated positioning to defend or recover balls collectively.
Attack executed with controlled timing to disrupt blockers.
Setter controls the pace of play by varying set speed.
Set delivered through a narrow opening between blockers.
Hit or set aimed through a gap in the opponent’s formation.
Defensive positioning to recover a soft tip over the net.
Spike imparting forward spin for sharper trajectory.
Serve with forward spin to increase speed and downward trajectory.
Positioning to maintain defensive structure while shifting to offense.
Pass executed with arms below the waist, often for short balls.

Positioning beneath the net to recover misdirected balls.
Soft attack aimed to surprise defenders.
Attack intended to turn the momentum against a stronger team.

Defensive positioning on the non-dominant attack side.
Spike directed sharply toward the sideline.

Defensive alignment forming a criss-cross to cover the court.
Approach forming a Y-shape to adjust to set direction.
Defensive alignment to cover assigned court areas effectively.
Serve that directly scores a point without being touched.
Attack executed from the back row, behind the 3-meter line.
Defensive positioning behind front-row players.
Defensive dig executed in the backcourt.
Defending near the back boundary line.
Serve aimed along or near the back boundary line.

Positioning to cover a block assisted by teammates.
Practice steps and movement for effective blocking.
Training to extend hands over the net effectively.
Angle formed by hands and arms to cover attackers.
Exercise to improve timing and hand positioning in blocks.
Spike directed to strike the opponent’s court near the sideline or endline.
Serve that curves sharply and unpredictably in the air.
Pass that first touches the floor before reaching a teammate.
Defensive positioning after an opponent’s surprise attack.
Alignment of blockers to cover maximum net area.
Hitter crosses behind or in front of a teammate to hit.
Switching court positions to defend effectively.

Set delivered under pressure with minimal room for error.
Serve with spin causing it to cut sharply sideways.

Exercise focused on improving digs, passes, and coverage.
Attack executed later than usual to deceive blockers.
Set intentionally delayed to alter hitter timing.
Defensive positioning along diagonal lines of the court.
Positioning after a teammate digs the ball.

Accidental two-touch pass, usually a fault.
Two attackers hitting simultaneously to confuse blockers.
Serve followed immediately by a teammate’s aggressive play.

Hard-driven spike aimed at the opponent’s court.
Practice positioning for defending soft attacks.
Serve that drops quickly after crossing the net to catch opponents off guard.
Adjusting defensive positioning in response to opponents’ movements.
Setter delivers the ball before the attacker reaches optimal timing.
Defensive positioning near sideline areas.

Maximum arm extension to reach ball during block or attack.
Focusing on the ball at all times to improve reaction and precision.
Pretending to cover one area while shifting to another.
Deceptive action by setter pretending to set, then hitting.
Rapid transition from defense to offense to catch opponents unprepared.

Set that results in a point-winning attack.
